meanings.def: to have your home in a particular place
examples: to live in a house/a flat/an apartment
We used to live in London.
people living in rural areas
We live in a world where technological advance is the norm.
Where do you live?
She needs to find somewhere to live.
It's a great place to live.
Both her children still live at home.
He lived and worked there until his death in 2015.
(informal) Where do these plates live (= where are they usually kept)?
I live in an old farmhouse.
He lives in Cape Town.
I'm not going to live here permanently.
The couple have lived apart for two years.
She lives quite near here.
She's lived at this same address for four years.
They lived among the people of this remote island.
We went to live in Canada when I was three.
You can live there quite cheaply.
They live in a society that is among the most liberal in Western Europe.
Her family has lived in the community since 1962.

meanings.def: to remain alive
examples: The doctors said he only had six months to live.
Spiders can live for several days without food.
Women live longer than men in general.
Who wants to live forever? I don't.
live to do something She lived to see her first grandchild.
He lived to the age of 95.
I shall remember this day for as long as I live.
I absolutely could not live without my cell phone!

meanings.def: to be alive, especially at a particular time
examples: When did Handel live?
Luther lived at a time when the Bible was only available in Latin.
He's the greatest player who ever lived.

meanings.def: to spend your life in a particular way
examples: live + adv./prep. He lived in poverty most of his life.
to live in fear/peace/harmony
Most of the people live well, with nice houses and plenty to eat.
live something She lived a very peaceful life.
They lived their lives to the full.
live + noun She lived and died a single woman.
All she wanted was to get married and live happily ever after.
He was living quietly with his family.
He's now living a life of luxury in Australia.
She tried to live vicariously through her children.
They lived frugally off a diet of beans and lentils.
They'll have enough money to live comfortably.
Tonight she felt like living dangerously.
the need to live as harmoniously as possible with everyone else

meanings.def: to continue to exist or be remembered
examples: This moment will live in our memory for many years to come.
Her words have lived with me all my life.

meanings.def: to have a full and exciting life
examples: I don't want to be stuck in an office all my life—I want to live!

meanings.def: to have enough money to be able to live a very comfortable life
if two people are or live in each other’s pockets, they are too close to each other or spend too much time with each other
to still be alive after the time when you were expected to die
examples: He’s been living on borrowed time ever since his last heart attack.

meanings.def: to be doing something that other people are likely to soon stop you from doing
examples: According to the latest opinion polls, the government is living on borrowed time.

meanings.def: the way of life of a different social group, especially one much richer than you
to live a happy and comfortable life with no problems or responsibilities
examples: The two crooks had been living the life of Riley.
He planned to retire early and then lead the life of Riley.

meanings.def: to be very enthusiastic about something
examples: He just lives and breathes football.

meanings.def: used to say that you should accept other people’s opinions and behaviour even though they are different from your own
to earn money by clever or sometimes dishonest means
to have a way of life that seems perfect
examples: With her own TV show and a flat in Paris, she is living the dream.

meanings.def: to spend all the money you earn on basic needs such as food without being able to save any money
to behave as though society, etc. has not changed, when in fact it has
to live together and have a sexual relationship without being married
to enjoy yourself in an exciting way, usually spending a lot of money
to keep something important about yourself a secret from other people, so that they do not know what you really think, what you are really like, etc.
examples: He lived a lie for thirty years, ‘married’ to two women.

meanings.def: to have enough money to be able to afford expensive things, food, drink, etc.
to eat whatever food you can grow, kill or find yourself
to live or sleep outdoors, usually because you have no home and no money
examples: young people sleeping rough on the streets

meanings.def: used to say that although you have failed or had a bad experience, you will continue
to survive a difficult or dangerous experience so that you can tell others what really happened
to be unaware of popular culture and important events that are happening in the world
examples: Unless you’ve been living under a rock for the last few decades, you’ll be aware that Arctic sea ice is melting.

meanings.def: used to say that you hope somebody/something will live or last for a long time
examples: Long live the King!
Long live public libraries!

meanings.def: you should not criticize other people, because they will easily find ways of criticizing you
used to tell somebody that if they have not had a particular experience their life is not complete
examples: You've never been to New York? You haven't lived!

meanings.def: used to express surprise at something new or unexpected you have been told

idioms.def: to have enough money to be able to live a very comfortable life
if two people are or live in each other’s pockets, they are too close to each other or spend too much time with each other
to still be alive after the time when you were expected to die
examples: He’s been living on borrowed time ever since his last heart attack.
According to the latest opinion polls, the government is living on borrowed time.

idioms.def: the way of life of a different social group, especially one much richer than you
to live a happy and comfortable life with no problems or responsibilities
examples: The two crooks had been living the life of Riley.
He planned to retire early and then lead the life of Riley.

idioms.def: to be very enthusiastic about something
examples: He just lives and breathes football.

idioms.def: used to say that you should accept other people’s opinions and behaviour even though they are different from your own
to earn money by clever or sometimes dishonest means
to have a way of life that seems perfect
examples: With her own TV show and a flat in Paris, she is living the dream.

idioms.def: to spend all the money you earn on basic needs such as food without being able to save any money
to behave as though society, etc. has not changed, when in fact it has
to live together and have a sexual relationship without being married
to enjoy yourself in an exciting way, usually spending a lot of money
to keep something important about yourself a secret from other people, so that they do not know what you really think, what you are really like, etc.
examples: He lived a lie for thirty years, ‘married’ to two women.

idioms.idiom: live off the fat of the land
idioms.def: to have enough money to be able to afford expensive things, food, drink, etc.
to eat whatever food you can grow, kill or find yourself
to live or sleep outdoors, usually because you have no home and no money
examples: young people sleeping rough on the streets

idioms.def: used to say that although you have failed or had a bad experience, you will continue

idioms.idiom: live, etc. to tell the tale
idioms.def: to survive a difficult or dangerous experience so that you can tell others what really happened
to be unaware of popular culture and important events that are happening in the world
examples: Unless you’ve been living under a rock for the last few decades, you’ll be aware that Arctic sea ice is melting.

idioms.def: used to say that you hope somebody/something will live or last for a long time
examples: Long live the King!
Long live public libraries!

idioms.idiom: people (who live) in glass houses shouldn’t throw stones
idioms.def: you should not criticize other people, because they will easily find ways of criticizing you
used to tell somebody that if they have not had a particular experience their life is not complete
examples: You've never been to New York? You haven't lived!

idioms.def: used to express surprise at something new or unexpected you have been told

meanings.def: living; not dead
examples: live animals
the number of live births (= babies born alive)
We saw a real live rattlesnake!
I need to talk to a live person (= not a recording or computer).

meanings.def: sent out while the event is actually happening, not recorded first and broadcast later
examples: a live broadcast
live coverage of the World Cup
You're looking at live pictures from a Las Vegas courtroom.
a live report from our correspondent in Jerusalem
on live television/TV
a live video feed
Is the show live or recorded?

meanings.def: given or made when people are watching, not recorded
examples: The club has live music most nights.
the magic of a live performance
They're still one of the best live bands (= best at performing) around.
It was the first interview I'd done in front of a live audience (= with people watching).

meanings.def: made at a live performance, not in a recording studio
examples: a live recording made at Wembley Arena
the band’s new live album

meanings.def: connected to a source of electrical power
examples: That terminal is live.

meanings.def: still able to explode or light; ready for use
examples: live ammunition

meanings.def: live coals are burning or are still hot and red
live yogurt still contains the bacteria needed to turn milk into yogurt
of interest or importance at the present time
examples: Pollution is still very much a live issue.

meanings.def: functioning correctly, so that it is connected to another document or page on the internet
examples: Here are some live links to other aviation-related web pages.

meanings.def: a person who is lively and full of energy

idioms.def: a person who is lively and full of energy

meanings.def: broadcast at the time of an actual event; played or recorded at an actual performance
examples: The show is going out live.
We'll be reporting live from Beijing.
Three great local bands will be playing live.
I can watch the games live on TV.
Later we'll talk live with the former New York police commissioner.
The game will be televised live this evening.
The show will air live on June 10.
The trial was carried live on a Chicago radio station.
This concert comes to you live from Carnegie Hall.
The CD was recorded live at a concert given last year.
The band have never played this song live before.
The show was filmed live at the Arena.

meanings.def: to start; to become operational (= ready to be used)
examples: The student services project is to go live soon.
When does the new website go live?

idioms.def: to start; to become operational (= ready to be used)
examples: The student services project is to go live soon.
When does the new website go live?
